tweets.text:
RT @alliance: Congrats to @arespro (ALL10) on their launch.

Ares provides real-time market intelligence for prediction market traders.

btc and anthropic r unironically the same trade

ai automation -> unemployment -> helicopter money -> hard asset moon
RT @alliance: Brian Armstrong on market cycles https://t.co/3seWwLfETD
my personal token usage has gone up about 100x in the last 2mo
more concretely i see nothing wrong with the >half a trillion dollar 2026 capex by mag7

think ai is much less of a bubble than I thought 2mo ago

and pretty much everyone i know who used claude / codex in the last 2mo feels that way
the lion is bidding
google’s well-above-consensus capex guidance doesn’t not surprise me at all and is quite rational imo.

once in a while i get better investment ideas from doing than from reading. case in point after a month of coding i bought more hyperscalers and semis. amzn msft nvda tsm the whole 9 yards. the market is completely unprepared for how much compute will be needed.

there’s always some communication friction between a 10/10 engineer and a 10/10 domain expert. but if u could have a 8/10 engineer and a 8/10 domain expert in the same person, that person is going to be insanely productive.

epiphany after a month of coding:

ppl who r *pretty* good at coding and *pretty* good at another nontechnical field (without necessarily being a true expert in either) r going to be very, very, very powerful.

and this is probably my best advice for college students: get pretty

note_tweet.text:
epiphany after a month of coding:

ppl who r *pretty* good at coding and *pretty* good at another nontechnical field (without necessarily being a true expert in either) r going to be very, very, very powerful.

and this is probably my best advice for college students: get pretty good at coding and get pretty good at another nontechnical field.

tweets.text: here’s a thought experiment: if the only moat that the best software companies had was software, then incumbents with infinite engineering resources would’ve come in and killed them even in the pre-ai era. but they didn’t, why?

on the “software is dead” narrative:

my intuition is that ai makes strong software companies stronger and weak software companies weaker. this is because the moat of strong software companies was never software, but rather distribution, proprietary data, workflow integration,

note_tweet.text:
on the “software is dead” narrative:

my intuition is that ai makes strong software companies stronger and weak software companies weaker. this is because the moat of strong software companies was never software, but rather distribution, proprietary data, workflow integration, enterprise lockin, network effects, trust and compliance,  etc. whereas the moat of weak software companies was just… software. 

example of strong companies: msft

tweets.text: @sachelik i wonder if the end state is humans expressing creativity and steering the ship thru the markdown files

been claude coding for over a month and my journey has gone from v low level (eg "fix this pixel") to v high level (eg "here's the vision_statement.md. go and figure out how to execute while autonomously improving urself")

ive finally reached an abstraction level where claude is

note_tweet.text:
been claude coding for over a month and my journey has gone from v low level (eg "fix this pixel") to v high level (eg "here's the vision_statement.md. go and figure out how to execute while autonomously improving urself")

ive finally reached an abstraction level where claude is starting to break. but as models/tooling/compute continue to improve i don't see why i can't continue to move up the abstraction ladder.

to the point where i'm starting to wonder if anthropic already has self-improving models (despite dario saying they r months to couple years away from it).

also wondering how frighteningly close we r to a world where "hey claude, build a billion dollar company. make no mistakes" is no longer a meme.

tweets.text: RT @alliance: Ben Horowitz on CEO psychology https://t.co/St3TLZ4rhd

on this year’s big ipos:

no matter how bullish u r on these companies long term (as i am), understand that *they* choose when and at what price they sell the shares to u. this is peak adverse selection.

best time to buy their shares is probably during the subsequent market wide

note_tweet.text:
